After processing your submission the notary service generates a log.  This JSON file holds information about your submission, including errors and warnings.
Always check the notary log, even if notarization succeeds, because it might contain warnings that you can fix prior to your next submission.

subcommand to save your app-specific password to the keychain:

code: % xcrun notarytool store-credentials PROFILE --apple-id APPLE_ID --team-id TEAM_ID

inlineContent.text: is a name that you assign to these credentials.  You might use a value like
The command prompts you to enter your app-specific password.  Once you do that, it checks that the password is valid and, if so, stores the credentials in your keychain with the specified profile.
To use these credentials in subsequent commands, supply the profile name using the
option.  For example, to get a notarization history:

content.text: Enable notarization on an older version of macOS

inlineContent.text: The first version of Xcode to include
is Xcode 13.  It requires macOS 11.3.  It is, however, possible to notarize on earlier systems, all the way back to macOS 10.15.  To do this, copy
from a system with Xcode or the Command Line Tools package installed, as described in the previous section.
to work back to macOS 10.15 regardless of the minimum system version of the product in which it’s contained.  This is a special case and does not apply to any other component within Xcode.
, the notary service sends you an email when it’s done processing your submission.  It doesn’t do this when you notarize with
.  If you were previously relying on this email to trigger events in your workflow, consider one of the following
, which waits for your submission to complete
, which notifies you when your submission is complete

Updated to include the announced end date for

abstract.text: Notarize your app from the command line to handle special distribution cases.
Give users even more confidence in your macOS software by submitting it to Apple for notarization.
Learn how the keychain on macOS differs from other Apple platforms.

doc://com.apple.documentation/documentat.title: TN3137: On Mac keychain APIs and implementations

abstract.text: Use the Terminal app to read the documentation for low-level UNIX tools and APIs.
Learn about specific development topics through these in-depth technical articles.
Explore the various Wi-Fi APIs available on iOS and their expected use cases.
Learn techniques to help debug any coordinate space issue.
